Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AToL: ACCESS DNA viruses: A Comprehensive survey of Circular Eukaryotic Single-Stranded DNA viruses in Invertebrates and Fungi
Award.AbstractNarration:
Viruses affect all forms of cellular life; however, it is extremely difficult to trace their evolutionary history. This project will reconstruct the phylogeny of an understudied branch of the viral tree of life: that of circular eukaryotic single-stranded DNA (CESS) viruses. CESS viruses are the smallest known viruses, yet they include pathogens with devastating impacts on agriculture worldwide. Recently, general environmental sampling has uncovered a diversity of CESS viruses that are only distantly related to these pathogens and has shown that they infect a wider range of hosts than previously thought, including insects and fungi. This project systematically tests previously unexplored hosts to discover, sequence, and classify their CESS viruses. Phylogenetic analyses will then determine how all CESS viruses are related to one another, providing a framework for classifying the CESS viral tree of life.

Broader impacts of this research include training of graduate students, undergraduates, and postdocs, as well as K-12 outreach and creation of web-based resources for the scientific and general public. Middle school students will be involved in collecting invertebrate samples, which will be processed during a virology training workshop for graduate students and postdocs on CESS virus genomics. Project results will be displayed on a website to increase public knowledge about CESS viruses, and bioinformatics tools will be shared freely with the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historically, viruses encoding a replication-associated protein (Rep) within a circular, single-stranded (ss)DNA genome have been of interest due to their negative impacts on agriculturally relevant organisms, including plants and livestock. However, studies investigating total viral DNA from environmental samples and unconventional organisms, such as insects, fungi, and protists, have unveiled an expansive diversity of circular Rep-encoding ssDNA (CRESS DNA) viruses. Since little is known about the diversity and ecology of CRESS DNA viruses associated with invertebrates and fungi, the primary goal of this project was to conduct a comprehensive survey of these viruses in undersampled taxa. We systematically tested more than 1000 specimens to discover, sequence, and classify their associated CRESS DNA viruses. The project resulted in the discovery of more than 80 novel CRESS DNA viral species, some of which represent the first viruses ever described from certain organisms (e.g., sea hares, anemones, millipedes). Moreover, phylogenetic analysis of the Rep, the most conserved and tractable CRESS DNA phylogenetic marker, indicates that the extensive CRESS DNA viral diversity retrieved from invertebrates dwarfs the diversity reported from vertebrates, plants, and fungi. Both terrestrial and aquatic arthropods, which harbor viral genomes that are only distantly related to currently classified viruses, were identified as hotspots of CRESS DNA viral diversity, providing insight into the host range and evolutionary history of these viruses.

In addition to significantly expanding our view of CRESS DNA viral diversity, this project enabled us to refine taxonomic frameworks for some of these viruses with the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. CRESS DNA viruses are emerging as a highly diverse and widespread group in the eukaryotic DNA viral world, with each report of novel genomes expanding the boundaries of this group. During the project period, the number of CRESS DNA viral families has doubled to accommodate their increasing diversity and many species remain unclassified. To facilitate understanding of this rapidly expanding group, we compiled a comprehensive review of CRESS DNA viruses that highlights their ubiquity, diversity, and evolutionary relationships.

The project provided training opportunities for students with diverse skillsets and backgrounds, including undergraduate (15), graduate (7), and high school (1) students. Students gained experience with molecular techniques such as DNA extractions, multiple displacement amplification, restriction enzyme digests, polymerase chain reaction, and cloning. More advanced students gained experience with bioinformatic analyses, including primer design, genome annotation, multiple sequence alignments and phylogenetic analyses. The vast majority of students are listed as authors on the 20 peer-reviewed manuscripts produced by the project and many gave presentations at local, national, and international conferences to various groups of interest.

We have also shared the project with the public through several major outreach events, including the Saint Petersburg Science Festival and Pint of Science, and held numerous events for local children through Girl Scouts, Girls Inc., Oceanography Camp for Girls, and the Great American Teach In. Notably, various CRESS DNA viral species were detected in specimens collected by outreach event participants. One of our publications describes a virus discovered from an insect specimen collected by a local Girl Scout Troop (who was acknowledged in the manuscript and the virus was named after the troop). In addition, we designed and conducted a two-day bilingual outreach activity in a rural area of Puerto Rico to teach seventh graders about viruses and insects and, in turn, the students helped us collect specimens for the project. Three new CRESS DNA viral species were identified in these specimens and the students are acknowledged in the publication describing these viruses. These forms of citizen science helped our research impact a broad audience and teach the public about viruses other than human pathogens.
